unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about understanding shopping prices, right? It's a pretty common thing to wonder about, especially with all the discounts and offers floating around. For example, you might see something like "Buy 2 get 1 free" or "50% off" – but what does it *really* mean?
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about understanding shopping prices, right? It's a pretty common thing to wonder about, especially with all the discounts and offers floating around. For example, you might see something like "Buy two get one free" or "fifty percent off" – but what does it really mean?

unnormalised: Let's say you're buying shirts. A shop has a deal: "Buy 2 shirts @ ₹499 each, get 1 free". Sounds amazing, right? But you're actually paying ₹998 for 3 shirts. That works out to around ₹332.66 per shirt. Often, shops will also advertise "Upto 70% off!" but when you actually browse, most items are only at a 20% discount. It's a marketing trick!
normalised: Let's say you're buying shirts. A shop has a deal: "Buy two shirts at rupee four hundred and ninety nine each, get one free". Sounds amazing, right? But you're actually paying rupee nine hundred and ninety eight for three shirts. That works out to around rupee three hundred thirty two point six six per shirt. Often, shops will also advertise "Up to seventy percent off!" but when you actually browse, most items are only at a twenty percent discount. It's a marketing trick!

unnormalised: Also, pay attention to "MRP" (Maximum Retail Price). Shops are not supposed to charge you more than the MRP. Sometimes you can even bargain a bit, especially at local markets like the one near my house in Karol Bagh. My mom always argues for a lower price, especially if she is paying with cash. unnormalised: Then there are online sales. I recently saw on Flipkart a "Big Billion Days" offer, with "Mobile phones starting @ ₹7999". But, of course, when you go to the website, you realize that only *some* phones are that price. The good ones are still expensive! Look carefully at the fine print – things like "T&C Apply" or "Limited Stock" can change the deal significantly.

unnormalised: Ultimately, the best way to understand shopping prices is to do a little math and compare prices across different shops, both online and offline. Websites like MySmartPrice can help. Don't be fooled by fancy advertising! Happy shopping, and remember to save some ₹ for chai!
